segments.text: What's the biggest misunderstanding about you?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Whenever you hear about somebody who's got ridiculous amounts of money, their values are different than your values.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You should be concerned about their agenda.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What's your biggest fear?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I'll be sad as my brain gets less capable.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: That disappoints me.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Tell me one behavior we all should adopt.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Reading a lot, being a student.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: That's a big part of my success.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Richest and most powerful men in the world.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Bill Gates has unleashed a technological revolution.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: that has changed our lives.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Bill Gates of 25 and Bill Gates of 70, any change that you feel personally?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: In my 20s, being a maniac was the right thing.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: My competitors would say, oh no, you work too hard.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I'd say, yes, I do.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: If you're in a race, your 20s, when you have no wife and no children, that's the time to do it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: If you get an opportunity to invite three Indians for dinner, who would that be?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: There was a mathematician, Ramanujan.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I would have loved to have met him.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Why do you think India is becoming a global talent capital for the world?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: We would hire people from India and bring them to the United States.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, both the United States and India were kind of mad at us because we were taking, you know, the smart people and moving them.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: In India, a lot of kids also fight with their parents on the inheritance.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Have your kids ever spoken to you?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Ha ha.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Before we start today's episode, all I want to say is thank you to each and every one of you.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I'm really grateful that we were able to sit down with one of the most influential men in the world, the Bill Gates.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I have been this young boy who always used to hear stories about this man, about the kind of money he has made, the kind of lives he's impacting, the kind of things he's building through Microsoft.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: From there,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: to be sitting in front of him.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: It was surreal.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: When I started the conversation, you could see it on my face that I was really nervous, really scared.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I didn't know what to talk about, but as we went in the conversation, the podcaster in me took over and we spoke about his fears, his misunderstandings, the mission and what is he doing today.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Today I want you to see this episode from a lens of a 20 year old sitting with Bill Gates,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: and figuring out what goes on in his brain.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: This episode is truly special because I could have never thought that Bill Gates will be on our podcast this soon in our journey.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I always had a belief that we will be able to sit down with the smartest people around the world, but it'll happen this soon.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I can't believe this right now.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I just want you to enjoy this episode the way I did.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I want you to sink in that this is happening because it's not sinking in with me.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And I just want to tell you that there are more episodes coming.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So keep supporting us and hit the subscribe button right now.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Welcome on Figuring Out Sir.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I'll tell you a little story.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So during the pandemic, me and my sister, we were watching the Netflix documentary.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: inside Bill's brain and halfway through it, I told my sister that, hey, you know what, like one day I'll sit with Bill Gates and I'll directly speak to him and get inside his brain.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And just randomly, and she was laughing.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So this one's for you.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You did it.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So it's an opportunity.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I don't know how it just came out of my mouth and it's happening today.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So thank you so much for doing this.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You've come to India quite often.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Tell me something that you've observed about India, which a lot of people don't know about.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Well, people probably, you know, because they're here all the time, you know, they probably don't recognize how much things have changed.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And if you go away and come back, then you see, wow, you know, the level of entrepreneurship and the, you know, the amount of innovation that's actually taking place here.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Uh, it's pretty fantastic.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And, you know, for the foundation, we've been here originally, uh, because a lot of the health challenges were here and we still care a lot about that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But, uh, now a lot of our invention is being done here, whether it's, uh, well vaccines, obviously, uh, we have some incredible partnerships, but it's broadening to, you know,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: better seeds, better diagnostics, the ways that we can use AI for health or education.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So the innovation ecosystem has really exploded, and that's going to be great for India.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's going to be great for the world.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So when you meet other leaders around the world or when you meet your billionaire friends, what's the first thing you tell them about India?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Is it the same thing that you just told me?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Yeah, we've had such a great experience in our work in India.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I encourage people to come and tap into the great things going on.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Is there anything specific you tell them?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Well, my connection with India goes all the way back to the Microsoft days, when we at first would hire people from India and bring them to the United States.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And both the United States and India were kind of mad at us, because we were taking the smart people and moving them.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And then they came back here to India and created the Microsoft India work, which has been absolutely fantastic.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So up until the year 2000, I mainly knew the tech scene.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Bangalore, Hyderabad.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Seeing the country more broadly, that's in my foundation work.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So Bihar, UP, seeing where we could partner and help with things.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I still wanna take more vacation here.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I've done it a little bit, but there's a lot of great places in India that I haven't been to.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Talking about Microsoft and taking people from here to US,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: people like Satya Nadella, Sundar Pichai, there have been incredible CEOs around the world.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Why do you think India is becoming a global talent capital for the world?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Do you think anything special here is out there?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Well, you know, 20% of the world's people live here in India.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And India's had a particular emphasis on, you know, engineering, software, you know, and turned out
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: a lot of top people.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And so when you get people like Sundar Satya, who are both great at engineering and management, that's a magic combination.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And so these companies are looking anywhere in the world to find that mix.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And so India's getting about its fair share of those top leadership positions.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And it partly comes from having great universities, not just the IITs, but starting with them, that's using the incredible talent that's here.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So talking about Indian talent, you do a lot of philanthropy work here, and you've met a lot of talented people here, a lot of rich people here as well.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Do you, and you believe that
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: all the money that rich people have, or like people who have made wealth for themselves, they should use it for charity work, they should pledge it.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: In India, there's a, usually a lot of people believe that as parents, it's their duty to save everything for their kids, for the inheritance, right?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Like the kids will get everything.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: What do you think is the right mindset?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Using all the money for pledging and giving it back to the society or giving it to the children?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Well, I think, you know, everybody gets to decide on that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, in my case, you know, my kids got a great upbringing education, but, you know, less than 1% of the the total wealth because I decided it wouldn't be a favor to them.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, it's not a dynasty.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, I'm not asking them to run Microsoft.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I want to give them a chance to have their own earnings and success.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: you know, be significant and not overshadowed by the incredible luck and good fortune I had.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And different families see that differently.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think the people who've made fortunes from technology are less dynastic and, you know, so they'll even, you know, take their capital.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: and give a lot of that away.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You can have a view of giving away your capital or just giving away your earnings.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And of course, I love all philanthropy, but the tech sector is probably the most aggressive about giving most of it away.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Not the other sectors.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You have not seen that in any other kind of industry where people try to give.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Not to the same degree.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It tends to be giving more of the
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: giving some portion of the profit as opposed to the actual base capital.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, in India, a lot of kids also fight with their parents on inheritance.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Have your kids ever spoken to you and be like, hey, why are you not giving us everything or anything?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Has it ever happened?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You know, you don't want your kids to ever be confused
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: about your support for them and your love for them.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And so I do think explaining early on your philosophy, you know, that you're going to treat them all equally and that you're going to give them incredible opportunities.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But that, you know, the highest calling for these resources is to go back to the neediest through the foundation.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And, you know, they've seen the
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: success of the foundation.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I hope they're very proud of the foundation.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I've seen cases where kids actually tell their parents to be more philanthropic.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think the younger generation sometimes actually is pushing against this idea of the wealth just being passed down mostly.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So, you know, every family is a bit different.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I have last question on India and then we'll get to the foundation work and try to understand you as well.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: If you get an opportunity to invite three Indians for dinner, dead or alive, who would that be?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Well, I get to spend time with, you know, some incredible people in Indian, you know, I get
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: time with the Prime Minister and understand his vision and how we fit into that, this, you know, 2047 thing that, you know, everything is lining up to try to achieve that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, I get to meet, there was a great scientist, Raj Bhan, who created the Department of Biotechnology.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: There was a mathematician, Ramanujan, who I would have loved to have met him because he was a
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, almost mysterious how he was so genius at what he was able to do.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, I got to work with Rotentata.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I'm getting to work with all of the amazing philanthropists and a lot of the innovators here.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, I get to see small companies early on.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I just went through some of these companies using AI.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: in health, some for profit, a few non-profit.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We had a great 25th year celebration and this great sitar artist came and that was a pretty special thing.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So it'd be hard for me to pick.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: There's so many incredible talents.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You can't pick three.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think I defend some people by not including them.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Fair, fair.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You were talking about small companies.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: If you were to start something from zero in India today, where would you put most of your time and what the first step you'll take?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Well, you'd mostly start a company because you think you enjoy working on something and you think you have a world-class understanding
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: a unique contribution.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: For me, that was software.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: For this day and age, if you think you understand fusion, that's great.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: If you're successful, which that's risky, you could really improve the world.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: AI is sort of today's equivalent of what I did when I was young to see, wow, the possibilities are
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: unlimited.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And so, you know, I'd probably be doing one of these new AI companies if I was starting out today.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Do you still feel there's opportunity, a lot of opportunities in AI to build something as significant as what you have built, or it's pretty late?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Well, you know, the big companies are putting a lot of money into it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And the number of companies globally is
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: is huge.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I mean, many people didn't even know these Chinese companies were doing all this work.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And yet some of the best results over the last six months have come from three or four of the models there.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So when I got going in computing, it was a very small set of people.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And people thought we were crazy that we set a computer on every desk and a computer in every home.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And that just seemed strange to people because they couldn't see the, they didn't get software and they didn't get the exponential improvement of the chips was making computing basically free.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So it's, I'd say it's tougher to get out in front.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: There will be new companies.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I mean, Nvidia is almost as valuable as
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Apple and Microsoft and yet they came into prominence only really in the last five or six years although they're about 15 years old.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So there are opportunities and there will be some new companies that use AI to achieve unbelievable success but it'll be two or three out of 10,000 and would I be able to do that again?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Hard to say.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You talked about like when you started, a lot of people thought that, oh, what are you doing?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: This is some random thing these guys are trying to do.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: They may be stupid.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: They may be thinking too big, whatever.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Right.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And over the time, every time you do something big, usually people do not understand you or anyone like not just you, like whoever wants to start something new and big.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: In today's world or as of today,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: What's the biggest misunderstanding about you?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: What do you think?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: What do people misunderstand about Bill Gates?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Well, whenever you hear about somebody who's got some degree of power or ridiculous amounts of money, you might think they have grand schemes and there's almost a sense that their values are different.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: than your values and that you should be concerned about their agenda.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Hopefully for the people who actually do know me and how much I love the foundation work and how I work with my friends or my kids, it's very different from the people who just think, oh, wow, he's one of these guys who's pushing levers.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: has too much money and too much authority.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So that people misunderstand about you and tell you about misunderstanding.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Have you made any major mistake that people don't know about?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Well, some of my mistakes are very public.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I mean, Microsoft, you know, we had lots of products that didn't work.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, we did a phone operating system and now, you know, Android, you know, took
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: that position.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So I certainly messed that up in a huge way.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: For the foundation, we often have multiple plans.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We wanted to have an HIV vaccine.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We don't have that yet.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We're working on a very cheap toilet, but it's still too expensive.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So that's taking a lot longer.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We don't have polio.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: eradication done, I'm still very committed to that, but it's taking a lot longer than we thought it would.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Talking about foundation work, you've impacted millions of lives and you spend a lot in making people's life better.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: What's your biggest challenge today?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Because somebody who's watching this might think that at your level with so much
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: power, influence, money, you can actually fix a lot of problems.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: What do you think is your problem?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: What challenges do you see here?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Well, I love the scientific challenges.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I mean, we still don't fully understand malnutrition.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We have some tools to reduce it that it's super exciting.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But, you know, I'm really pushing our research workers hard that, OK,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, we need to know more about that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, I do think getting money to help the very poorest countries, a lot of which are in Africa.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, Asia, you know, many of the countries are having good economic growth.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And Africa has a lot of unique governance or instability or disease challenges.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: telling people they should, you know, help out other humans, even though they're they're far away and speak a different language.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: That's not as easy as I thought it would be.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, right now, some of the rich countries, including my country, are cutting their aid budgets.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I'm I'm very disappointed that, you know, to me, that's not, you know, the golden rule of treating people like you'd like to be treated.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What do you think?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: all the people who are watching this, including me, young people should do so that we could convince more people to help other people.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Well, when you're young, if you're here in India, you can probably travel some modest distance, an hour or two, and see people who don't have the same opportunities you do.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: They're smart, but their school's not good, or they get
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: uh, some health problem and they're not able to access things.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I would say in India, you know, programs like the aspirational district program, India does, uh, talk openly about the places that are the worst off and that's, you know, that's pretty impressive.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Uh, you know, even issues like sanitation that governments, most governments, you know, you wouldn't catch them talking about toilets.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Uh, you know, this,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: country took on a pretty aggressive plan and made a lot of progress on that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So you can go out and see people and develop empathy without going too far.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And you've spent hours and hours and days in this country.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You've spent millions on vaccines and trying to take care of health care challenges.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: What's one problem you feel that money cannot fix?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You know there's a lot of talk about obesity and you know when I saw the prime minister he was talking about various yoga type things that you know people would adopt those but it's been hard you know not many countries have gotten the behavior change you know maybe India can pioneer some approaches there
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But frankly, and I'll sound like a technologist, the most promising thing is actually a class of drugs called these GLP-1 drugs that are going to go off patent and become cheap.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So I'm a little over-focused on a scientific solution.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So maybe a combination of that behavior change and the new tools.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But behavior change is hard.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We haven't succeeded in that as much as we'd like to.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Tell me one behavior we all should adopt.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Well, the behavior that's helped me is basically being a student all the time wanting to learn things and being pretty brutal with myself of do I really understand what's going on?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Do I understand some AI thing or
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: some disease thing.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And fortunately, I can meet with people who in many cases can help me understand.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And then knowledge, if you're careful about building your knowledge, it all kind of connects together.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But reading a lot, being a student, having people who can teach me, that's been not only fun for me, but also a big part of my success.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So all of people who are watching this actually feels pretty validated at this point.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Because this whole podcast is about learning from really, really incredible people like you.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And we have so many questions that we just keep asking to learn more, to learn more, to get inside brains.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So thanks for validation.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Perfect.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: What's fascinating for me this time in your journey, like this time your visit to India,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: The full Gates Foundation board is here, right?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And that's pretty unique and they get to experience India.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.speaker: Host

segments.speaker: Host
